title: Basic Editing
subtitle: Enough to get real work done — go cold turkey after this chapter

content.text: Chapter 3 — Basic Editing
Enough to get real work done. After this chapter, you should go cold turkey — use Vim for everything. You'll be slow at first, but that's how you build muscle memory.
3.1 More Ways into Insert Mode
You know {key:i} enters insert mode at the cursor. But Vim gives you five more entry points, each putting you exactly where you need to be:

rows: Adding to the end of a word
Insert at the start of the line
Append at the end of the line

content.caption: After pressing a at the end of 'greet' and typing '_all' — appended without moving

content.text: Each of these saves you a motion. Instead of pressing {key:i} and then navigating to the end of the line, just press {key:A}. Instead of pressing {key:i}, then {key:Enter} to make a new line, just press {key:o}. Pick the insert command that puts you where you need to be.

content.caption: After pressing o — a new line opened below, cursor in insert mode

content.text: A common pattern: move to a line with {key:j}/{key:k}, then press {key:A} to append at the end or {key:O} to add a line above. Fast and precise.

content.caption: Watch: Insert at Start of Line (60s)
Watch: Append at End of Line (60s)

content.text: 3.2 Word Motions
Moving character-by-character with {key:h} and {key:l} is slow. Word motions jump by words — much faster for navigating code.

rows: Forward to the start of the next word
Backward to the start of the current/previous word
Forward to the end of the current/next word
Backward to the end of the previous word

content.caption: After pressing w four times — cursor jumped word by word

content.text: What counts as a "word"? Vim defines a word as a sequence of letters, digits, and underscores — or a sequence of other non-blank characters. So in {key:my_var}, that's one word. But in {key:my-var}, that's three words ({key:my}, {key:-}, {key:var}) because the hyphen breaks the word boundary.
These four motions will become your bread and butter. You'll use {key:w} and {key:b} constantly to navigate within lines.

content.caption: Jumping forward by word with w
Watch: Back to End of Word (60s)

content.text: 3.3 Line Motions
Jump to specific positions on the current line:

rows: Go to column zero (the very start)
Go to the first non-whitespace character
Go to the end of the line

content.caption: After pressing ^ — cursor on the first non-whitespace character, skipping the indentation

content.text: The difference between {key:0} and {key:^} matters for indented code. {key:0} takes you to column zero — the leftmost position. {key:^} takes you to the first character that isn't a space or tab. In Python or any indented language, {key:^} is what you usually want.
{key:$} is especially useful combined with operators: {key:d}{key:$} deletes to the end of the line (same as {key:D}), {key:c}{key:$} changes to the end of the line (same as {key:C}).

content.caption: Jumping to the end of a line with $

content.text: 3.4 File Motions
Jump anywhere in the file:

rows: Go to the first line of the file
Go to the last line of the file

content.caption: After pressing G — cursor jumped to the last line of the file

content.text: These are the motions that make scrolling with {key:j} and {key:k} feel primitive. Need to check the top of a file? {key:g}{key:g}. Need the bottom? {key:G}. Got a compiler error on line 42? {key:4}{key:2}{key:G}. Three keystrokes and you're there.

content.caption: Jumping to the top of a file with gg
Watch: Go to Top of File (60s)
Watch: Go to Bottom of File (60s)

content.text: 3.5 Deleting Text
Now we meet Vim's most important concept: the operator + motion pattern. {key:d} is the delete operator. On its own, it waits for a motion to tell it what to delete:

rows: The character before the cursor (like Backspace)
From the cursor to the start of the next word
From the cursor to the end of the line

content.caption: After pressing dw — the first word is gone, text shifted left

content.text: This is your first taste of Vim's composable grammar: {key:d} is the verb (delete), and the motion is the noun (what to delete). Every motion you know works with {key:d}: {key:d}{key:j} deletes two lines, {key:d}{key:G} deletes to the end of the file, {key:d}{key:g}{key:g} deletes to the top. You already know a dozen delete commands just by combining {key:d} with the motions from the last three sections.

This is the key insight: in Vim, you don't memorize individual commands. You learn operators (verbs) and motions (nouns), and they multiply. Every new motion you learn automatically works with every operator you already know.

content.caption: After pressing dd — the entire first line is deleted
Watch: Delete to End of Line (60s)

content.text: 3.6 Changing Text
Change = delete + enter insert mode. The {key:c} operator deletes the specified text and immediately drops you into insert mode, ready to type the replacement.

rows: Change a word (delete it, start typing)
Substitute one character (delete it, enter insert mode)

content.caption: After pressing cw and typing 'fox' — the word was replaced in one smooth motion

content.text: The {key:c} operator follows the same grammar as {key:d}: {key:c}{key:w} changes a word, {key:c}{key:j} changes two lines, {key:c}{key:G} changes to the end of the file. Same motions, different operator. The grammar scales.
{key:c}{key:w} is one of the most common Vim commands. You'll use it dozens of times per hour when editing code — jump to a word, {key:c}{key:w}, type the replacement, {key:Esc}. Fast.

content.caption: Watch: Change to End of Line (60s)

content.text: 3.7 Yank and Put (Copy and Paste)
Vim calls it "yank" and "put" instead of "copy" and "paste." The {key:y} operator yanks (copies) text, and {key:p} puts (pastes) it.

rows: Put after the cursor (or below for lines)
Put before the cursor (or above for lines)

content.caption: After yy then p — the first line was yanked and pasted below

content.text: Two handy tricks with yank and put:
{key:d}{key:d}{key:p} — swap two lines. Delete a line (it's now in the paste register), then put it after the line below. Instant line swap.

content.label: Swap current line with the line below

content.text: {key:x}{key:p} — swap two characters. Delete a character, put it after the next one. Fixes typos like 'teh' → 'the' in two keystrokes.
Where does yanked text go? Into a register — Vim's clipboard. For now, just know that the most recent yank or delete is always available with {key:p}. We'll explore registers in detail in Chapter 12.
3.8 Replace
Sometimes you just need to fix one character. {key:r}{key:X} replaces the character under the cursor with {key:X} — without entering insert mode. No mode switch, no {key:Esc} needed.

content.label: Replace character under cursor with X

content.caption: After pressing rX — the first character was replaced with X, still in normal mode

content.text: This is a micro-optimization that adds up. Need to change a comma to a semicolon? {key:r}{key:;}. Need to fix a capitalization? {key:r}{key:G}. One motion, one keystroke, done.

content.caption: Replacing a single character with r
